title: How to successfully appeal unfair benefit and Universal Credit sanctions
text:

If you're seen to have done something wrong, your benefits can be cut or even stopped entirely.

Worse, single parents, care leavers and people with disabilities "disproportionately vulnerable" to sanctions according to a recent report from Work and Pensions Committee.

But unfair sanction can be challenged if you know how.

Theresa Harris from legal charity Advicenow said: “If you think you have had your money stopped or cut unfairly you should think about appealing.

“You could get a lot of money back."

To help, charity Law For Life has offered a full guide to how people are sanctioned, what grounds you can appeal on and where to go to get the money back and what you need to tell them.

Here's their advice:

Sanctions explained

(Image: E+)

The Government expects people claiming benefits such as Universal Credit to meet the work-related conditions set out in their "Claimant Commitment".

If you don't the Job Centre can sanction you.

The average Universal Credit sanction is 31 days according to the DWP, but some can run for much longer.

Low level sanctions can be imposed for:

Missing an interview with an adviser at the Jobcentre

Refusing to take part in a training course or losing your place because you behaved badly

Not doing something else in your Claimant Commitment to get work or increase your earnings

Medium level sanctions can be imposed for things like:

Not taking all reasonable action to find paid work or increase your earnings

Not being available to start work or attend interviews

High level sanction are imposed for things like:

Leaving a job voluntarily

Losing a job because you behaved badly

Not applying for a job that the Jobcentre expected you to apply for

Not taking up a job that was offered to you

Losing pay if you are in paid work without a good reason

How to challenge a sanction

(Image: Newcastle Chronicle)

You can either challenge the length of the sanction or the sanction itself if you think it's unfair.

You can check to see if the length of your sanction is correct here .

There are three ways to challenge a sanction:

Ask DWP for a 'mandatory reconsideration’, then appeal

Make a complaint

Take your case to court if you were discriminated against because of your disability

You don't have to choose between these methods, but it's normally best to start by asking the DWP to reconsider their decision, called a mandatory reconsideration, before or at the same time as making a complaint.

You can ask in writing, on your online journal if you have one, over the phone or in person.

It's best to do it in writing if you can (and keep a copy) because then you have proof.

The letter or notification in your online account telling you about the sanction should also tell you how to challenge.

This should include the reason for your sanction, it's length and how much money is being stopped.

If you think discrimination has played a part, get advice quickly, as there are time limits for taking a claim.

The bad news is you might get lower or or no payments while the challenge is underway.

To compensate for that, you might be able to claim a hardship payment or other benefits during this time instead.

Valid reasons a sanction could be wrong

(Image: Getty Images)

Here are some of the main reasons a sanction can be judged incorrect:

The Jobcentre says you failed to do something, but you did do it

You have a good reason for what you did or didn’t do

The Jobcentre didn’t explain to you properly what you had to do, or what would happen if you didn’t do it

You have been sanctioned for something you weren’t asked to do

You have been given the wrong sanction (check you’ve been given the right sanction)

You need to send copies of evidence to back up what you say so keeping records is key.

And don't be put it off - you don't need to write a long explanation and or use the ‘right language’ for people to agree with you.

If you can, write a detailed letter on a computer and keep a copy. That way you will be able to use the letter again if you have to ask for an appeal.

If you have any extra evidence you think could help - such as a letter from your doctor, receipt or ticket which shows your whereabouts etc - send a copy of that too.

Why you should always appeal

(Image: PA)

If the mandatory reconsideration doesn't work, keep going. Many cases turned down at mandatory reconsideration but are successful at appeal.

But you do need to wait until you have asked the DWP for a ‘mandatory reconsideration’ before appealing.

You appeal to an independent tribunal called the First Tier tribunal. This is part of the Court Service. It is nothing to do with the DWP.

You need to use the form SSCS1 to ask for an appeal. You can download it from the HMCTS website.

The HMCTS will send a copy of your appeal to the DWP and ask them to explain how they came to their decision.

The DWP must do this within 28 days, although they can ask for an extension. You will receive a copy of their response.

Don’t be put off by the size of it. Keep it safe. You will need it to prepare for your hearing.

Making a complaint

(Image: Getty)

You can also complain to the Jobcentre and your Member of Parliament (MP) about the service you received or if you sanctioned unfairly.

Write to their office and send a copy of the letter to the Jobcentre dealing with your case. The Jobcentre may take your complaint more seriously when they see the local MP is involved.

For example, if you are sanctioned without being given the chance to explain your version of events or if the DWP failed to take into account a health condition when setting your work-related requirements.

Ask your local CAB or other advice service if you need help to write this letter.

You can find the complete guide to appealing a sanction here.
description: It seems even the smallest mistake can see your benefits stopped, blocked or reduced - with millions seeing Universal Credit payments reduced already - this is what you can do about it
